content: The Act may be cited as the "No Taxation Without Representation Act of 2006". The residents of the District of Columbia, who pay Federal income taxes and have fought in every American war, are denied voting representation in Congress. This goes against the principle of one person, one vote, and they are required to pay taxes without representation. Despite being denied voting representation, residents of the Nation's Capital rank third in per capita income taxes paid to the Federal Government. Unequal voting representation contradicts the founding principles of the Nation and the beliefs of the American people today. The District of Columbia will be treated as a State for representation in Congress. The Mayor of the District of Columbia will issue a proclamation for elections to fill Senate and House seats within 30 days of the Act's enactment. The elections will include a primary and general election, with officers chosen by popular vote of District residents, following the same rules as local elections. In the first election of Senators from the District of Columbia, the 2 senatorial offices shall be separately identified and designated. The results of the election shall be certified by the Mayor of the District of Columbia as required by law. The Senators and Representative shall be entitled to seats in Congress and all rights. The Senators and Representative from the District of Columbia shall be entitled to seats in Congress and all the rights and privileges of Senators and Representatives of the States in the United States Congress. Upon enactment of this Act, the District of Columbia will have 1 additional Representative in the House of Representatives until the next reapportionment. The House of Representatives will permanently increase by 1 seat for future reapportionment. The District of Columbia will be entitled to as many seats as a similarly populous State upon reapportionment. Elections for House members and Senators from the District of Columbia will be provided for. The District of Columbia Elections Code of 1955 is amended to change references from "the Delegate to the House of Representatives" to "the Representative in the Congress, Senator." This includes adjustments in sections 1, 2, and 8 of the code. The District of Columbia Elections Code of 1955 is amended to change references from "Delegate to the House of Representatives" to "Representative in the Congress, Senator" in various sections of the code. The District of Columbia Elections Code of 1955 is amended to address vacancies in the office of Representative in the Congress and Senator, with the Mayor appointing successors to complete the remainder of the term of office. The legislation also outlines the transition process for the District of Columbia Delegate until the first Representative from the District of Columbia is seated in the House of Representatives. The District of Columbia Delegate Act repeals sections 202 and 204, restoring or reviving previous laws. The amendments apply to future elections of Representatives and Senators from the District of Columbia. SEC. 7. REPEAL OF OFFICES OF STATEHOOD REPRESENTATIVE AND SENATOR. In summary, the text chunk discusses amendments to the District of Columbia Statehood Constitutional Convention Initiative of 1979, including changes to the number of voting members in the statehood commission and the repeal of certain offices related to statehood representation. The text chunk discusses the repeal of certain sections related to the District of Columbia Statehood Constitutional Convention Initiative of 1979, including authorization of appropriations, honoraria limitations, application of campaign finance laws, and amendments to the District of Columbia Elections Code of 1955. The amendments made by this section will take effect upon the taking office of the first Representative and Senators from the District of Columbia pursuant to this Act.
